DOC.HEAD: Judge Approves Sale of Braniff Gates to American Airlines
DOC.TEXT: A federal bankruptcy judge on Monday gave cash-poor Braniff Inc. permission to sell valuable takeoff and landing slots in Chicago and New York to American Airlines. Braniff arranged an emergency hearing in federal bankruptcy court and obtained approval to sell one slot at New York's LaGuardia Airport and three slots at Chicago's O'Hare International Airport to American for $400,000. On Dec. 7, Braniff won court permission to sell an airport gate in Fort Myers, Fla., to American for $2.15 million. U.S. Bankruptcy Judge C. Timothy Corcoran III approved the sale on condition that $750,000 be set aside in case Braniff is later liquidated. Corcoran indicated he would continue requiring some proceeds of asset sales to be held in escrow, saying he was worried that nothing would remain for creditors if Braniff were to be liquidated. Braniff creditors requested Monday that the $400,000 from the slot sale be placed in escrow with the revenue generated from the Fort Myers gate sale. Braniff attorneys agreed to the request. Since filing for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection Sept. 28 and drastically reducing staff and flights, Braniff has existed on emergency infusions of cash from the sale of assets. The Orlando-based carrier stopped operating all but a few charter flights and laid off most of its remaining employees Nov. 7. Its workforce is down to 275 employees from more than 4,800 before the bankruptcy filing. Lawyers involved in Braniff's bankruptcy proceeding say that by selling its assets, the carrier is trying to gain more operating time until it can devise a reorganization plan.
